send.title: Send payment

info.none: No memo. Use this if the recipient is not expecting a memo.
info.text: Free text up to 28 bytes. Often used for allocation in simple payments.
info.id: Numeric ID (uint64). Many exchanges use a Memo ID for the allocation of deposits.
info.hash: 32-byte SHA-256 hash (as a 64-digit hexadecimal string). Used by services for references.
info.return: 32-byte hash for returns. Used for returns (MEMO_RETURN).

createAccount.muxedInfo: The Muxed-ID creates an M-address (M...). It points to the same account as the regular address (G...).
createAccount.muxedIdInvalid: The Muxed-ID must be an integer between 0 and 18,446,744,073,709,551,615.
createAccount.muxedActivationInfo: Muxed addresses are alias addresses. They do not need to be activated separately.

seo.title: Create/manage a Muxed account
seo.description: Create and manage Muxed Address Aliases (M...) for a Stellar account. Generate IDs, add labels/notes, export/import as CSV.

muxed.title: Create/Manage Muxed Account
muxed.explainer: Generate alias addresses (M...) with a unique muxed-ID for an existing account. The alias address always refers to the same account.

info.title: What is a muxed account?
info.intro1: A Muxed account combines a regular account address (G-address) with an additional 64-bit Muxed ID.
info.intro2: Technically, it is an alias that always points to the same base account but is distinctly identifiable by the ID.
info.purposeText: Muxed accounts are used to manage many subaccounts under a single Stellar address‚Äîideal when many deposits/withdrawals are processed through a shared main account but every transaction needs to be assigned to a person, department, or project.
info.examplesTitle: Examples ‚Äì what are muxed accounts useful for?

examples.ex1: Company Payments: Each employee is assigned a unique Muxed ID to ensure that salary payments can be accurately attributed.
examples.ex2: Exchanges or platforms: Each user receives their own Muxed ID so that deposits made into a shared wallet are automatically recorded correctly.
examples.ex3: Projects or sub-accounts: An organization can allocate budgets or revenues to individual projects.
examples.ex4: Customer assignment: One M-address per customer; the ID corresponds to the customer ID ‚Äì payments can be clearly assigned, even without a memo.
examples.ex5: Services without a memo: Differentiate deposits when the service does not support memos.
examples.ex6: Payouts/Payroll Runs: One M‚Äëaddress per employee/partner for internal accounting and reports.
examples.ex7: Shop/Orders: One M-address per order; refunds can be assigned to the order.
examples.ex8: Departments/Cost Centers: IDs as cost centers; automatically group payments by area.
examples.ex9: Multi-tenant services: Each tenant receives their own M-address under the same base account.

info.pageTitle: What this page does on the SKM
info.pageDesc: This page is used to manage the muxed accounts of your currently selected Stellar account:

createItems.i1: Generates new muxed addresses (M...) from your base address (G...).
createItems.i2: Optional with label (name) and note (e.g., project or purpose).

importItems.i1: Mass creation of Muxed accounts, e.g., from an employee list.

exportItems.i1: Export all stored entries as a CSV.
exportItems.i2: Fields: basePublicKey, muxedId, muxedAddress, label, note, createdAt.

templateItems.i1: Create an empty CSV file with column headers muxedId,label,note.
templateItems.i2: Useful for HR or accounting departments in preparing new entries.

manageItems.i1: All stored muxed addresses are displayed in a table.
manageItems.i2: Selection, deletion, and label/note management directly possible.

info.shortText: Muxed accounts make your Stellar account granular and trackable‚Äîideal for organizations that process many payments through a central account but still want to uniquely assign each transaction.

muxed.baseAccountInfo: This account technically remains the owner. The Muxed address (M...) merely points to this account.
muxed.countInfo: Number of new Muxed addresses, consecutive IDs.
muxed.tooMany: Please create no more than 100 at a time.
muxed.rangeOverflow: The ID range exceeds the maximum allowed muxed ID.
muxed.label: Designation

import.hint: Import supports CSV with headers. Delimiters such as commas, semicolons, and tabs are automatically detected. Unknown columns are ignored. Formats include: extended (network, basePublicKey, muxedId, label, note, createdAt) or template (muxedId, label, note).

glossary.pageIntro: Here you will find important words from the blockchain world and the Stellar network. Everything is explained in simple terms.
glossary.searchHint: The search finds words and explanations.

blockchain.title: Blockchain
blockchain.short: Shared digital ledger - many computers store the same entries.
blockchain.desc: A blockchain is like a digital ledger. Many computers store the same entries, so no one can secretly alter anything.

wallet.title: Wallet
wallet.short: Digital wallet that manages your keys.
wallet.desc: A wallet is your digital purse. It manages the keys you need to access your account and send transactions. A wallet can be a program, an app, or even just a piece of paper with your private key.

account.title: Account
account.short: A blockchain account can hold assets and send transactions.
account.desc: An account is the place on the blockchain where your assets are held. An account has a public address that starts with G. Multiple wallets can access the same account if they have the correct key.

addressG.title: G-Address
addressG.short: The public main address of a Stellar account (begins with G).
addressG.desc: The G-address is the main address of a Stellar account. It starts with the letter G. You provide it to others so they can send something to you.

publicKey.title: Public key
publicKey.short: Address you are allowed to share; usually the G-address with Stellar.
publicKey.desc: The public key is the address you are allowed to show. In Stellar, this is the G-address. Others use it to send you money.

privateKey.title: Secret key
privateKey.short: Password to the account ‚Äì never share.
privateKey.desc: The secret key is your password for the account. Anyone who has this key can move your money. Never share it.

addressFederation.title: Federation address
addressFederation.short: Short address like email points to a G address.
addressFederation.desc: A federation address looks like an email. Example: name*domain.com. This short address points to a regular G address. It's easier to remember.

addressMuxed.title: Muxed account
addressMuxed.short: M-address with additional ID ‚Äì shares a base account.
addressMuxed.desc: An M-address points to an existing Stellar account but also has its own number (ID). This allows, for example, distinguishing multiple people or departments under the same G-address. Technically, the funds still belong to the main account.

multisig.title: Multisignature
multisig.short: Important actions require more than just a signature.
multisig.desc: Multi-sig stands for multiple signatures. An important action requires more than one key. For example, you and a second key must both agree before something can be sent. This makes theft more difficult.

trustline.title: Trustline
trustline.short: Agreement to hold a token from a specific issuer.
trustline.desc:
A trustline is like a "yes, I accept this token." By doing so, you're indicating that your account is ready to hold a specific token from a specific issuer. Without a trustline, you cannot receive this token.

Example: A trustline is specified as CODE:ISSUER. For EURT from the issuer GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y‚Ä¶, it is EURT:GDUKMGUGDZQK6Y‚Ä¶.

token.title: Token
token.short: Digital unit ‚Äì e.g., money, points, or credit.
token.desc: A token is a digital unit on the blockchain. A token can represent money, or points, or credits for a service.

asset.title: Asset
asset.short: Tokens on Stellar are always linked to an issuer.
asset.desc: On Stellar, a token is called an asset. An asset is always linked to an issuer account. For example, an account can issue a Euro token. This Euro token is then an asset.

xlm.title: XLM
xlm.short: Native currency of Stellar for fees and activation.
xlm.desc: XLM is the base currency of Stellar. You need XLM to pay fees and to start a new account.

mainnet.title: Mainnet
mainnet.short: Real Stellar network with true value.
mainnet.desc: The real Stellar network with actual value. Transactions are final, and fees are paid in real XLM.

testnet.title: Testnet
testnet.short: Public practice network without real value.
testnet.desc: A public practice network. Tokens have no real value. Ideal for learning and experimenting without risk.

memo.title: Memo
memo.desc: A memo is a small note that you can send along with a transaction. Often, an exchange requires a specific memo so that it knows to whom the money belongs.

transaction.title: Transaction
transaction.short: Action on the blockchain, such as payment or trustline.
transaction.desc: A transaction is an action on the blockchain. For example, sending money or creating a trust line. A transaction is permanently stored once it is confirmed.

fee.title: Fee
fee.desc: The fee is a very small amount that you pay with each transaction. The fee goes to the network. With Stellar, the fees are very low.

ledger.title: Ledger
ledger.short: Chain of confirmed data and balances.
ledger.desc: The ledger is the chain of all confirmed data. It shows which accounts possess how much and which transactions have occurred. Anyone can check the ledger.

horizon.title: Horizon
horizon.short: API service through which apps communicate with Stellar.
horizon.desc: Horizon is the service through which programs interact with the Stellar blockchain. Our tool queries Horizon to load account balances and transactions.

anchor.title: Anchor
anchor.short: Company connecting fiat money with Stellar.
anchor.desc: An Anchor is a company that connects real money like Euro or Dollar with Stellar. For example, you give the Anchor Euros and receive a Euro token on Stellar in return.

exchange.title: Stock exchange
exchange.short: Place to buy and sell tokens.
exchange.desc: An exchange is a place where you can buy or sell tokens. Many exchanges require a KYC process, which is an identity verification, before you can withdraw money in euros or francs.

dex.title: DEX
dex.short: Decentralized exchange directly on the blockchain.
dex.desc: DEX stands for Decentralized Exchange. Here, people trade directly with each other on the blockchain. There is no single operator. Stellar has a DEX built directly in.

liquidityPool.title: Liquidity pool
liquidityPool.short: Common pool with two tokens for immediate exchange.
liquidityPool.desc: A liquidity pool is a shared pool consisting of two tokens. People deposit both tokens into it. Others are then allowed to instantly exchange these tokens. In return, the depositors earn small fees.

balanceClaimable.title: Claimable Balance
balanceClaimable.short: Reserved funds that you still need to accept.
balanceClaimable.desc: A Claimable Balance is money that is already reserved for you, but you still need to claim it. It only goes into your account once you accept it.

protocolUpdate.title: Protocol Update
protocolUpdate.desc: A protocol update is an upgrade of the rules in the Stellar network, such as new features or security changes. All nodes in the network must use the same rules.

soroban.title: Soroban
soroban.desc: Soroban is the smart contract system of Stellar. A smart contract is program code on the blockchain. The code can independently verify rules and trigger actions without a bank intermediary.

mode.realWarning: Notice: Actual trustline(s) will be deleted.

deleted.notFound: No erasable trustlines found ‚Äì all still contain balances.

trustline.nonZeroBalance: This trustline cannot be deleted because it still contains a balance.
trustline.onlyZeroBalanceInfo: Only trustlines with a balance of 0 can be deleted.

flag.compromised: Warning: This recipient is marked as compromised in your trust list.
flag.deactivated: Note: This recipient is marked as disabled in your trust list.

lesson1.title: What is a blockchain?
lesson1.learningOutcome: A blockchain is an immutable digital ledger that is collectively verified by everyone.

lesson2.title: Understand Stellar
lesson2.goal: Know the difference from other blockchains.
lesson2.task: Send token to friend (simulation) and view speed
lesson2.learningOutcome: Stellar is fast, inexpensive, and without mining.

lesson3.title: Public & Privacy
lesson3.task: View public transaction and guess if one knows who the sender is.
lesson3.learningOutcome: Everything is visible, but no one knows the real name.

lesson4.title: Your account
lesson4.goal: Understanding the structure and significance of Public/Secret Key
lesson4.task: Matching Game: What is public, what is secret
lesson4.learningOutcome: Only the secret key grants access; the public key can be shared.

lesson5.title: Send & Receive
lesson5.goal: Understanding How Transactions and Trustlines Work
lesson5.task: Execute test shipment and view fee.
lesson5.learningOutcome: Each transaction incurs a small fee; Trustline = permission to receive.

lesson6.title: Token & Trading
lesson6.task: Place a token on a virtual marketplace and monitor the price change.
lesson6.learningOutcome: Price is determined by supply and demand.

lesson7.title: Security
lesson7.task: Sorting correct/incorrect actions; detecting fake tokens
lesson7.learningOutcome: Confidentiality of the key, secure storage, and using the testnet.

lesson8.title: Verification & Identity
lesson8.learningOutcome: KYC = Identity verification, verification shows trustworthy tokens.

lesson9.title: Zero Knowledge
lesson9.task: Example scenario 'I am over 18' without showing a birthdate
lesson9.learningOutcome: One can prove something without revealing secrets.

lesson10.title: Practice with SKM
lesson10.task: Create an account in the testnet, activate it, set a trustline, and send tokens.
lesson10.learningOutcome: Understand the technical processes of a transaction.

lesson11.title: Responsibility
lesson11.task: Decision game: act correctly or not
lesson11.learningOutcome: Blockchain is final; due diligence is a must.

lesson12.title: Conclusion / Playful Learning
lesson12.learningOutcome: Review what you've learned, recognize your own progress.
